Introduction

Seborrheic keratoses (SKs) are classically brown hyperkeratotic papules or plaques with a warty and "stuck-on" appearance.  They are common in older adults and are themselves benign.  However, a sudden eruption of multiple SKs may be a sign of occult internal malignancy.

Risk factors



Factors that increase the risk of developing SKs include the following:

  • Older age (age >50)


  • Positive family history


  • Light skin


  • Pregnancy, estrogen replacement therapy


  • Underlying malignancy, which can cause sudden onset of multiple SKs (Leser-Trélat sign)

Etiology



The etiology of SK is not fully understood; however, it is frequently associated with activating mutations of the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene.

Clinical presentation



SKs classically develop in older adults and present as brown, hyperkeratotic papules or plaques with a warty and "stuck-on" appearance.  These lesions typically remain stable over time and are minimally symptomatic (asymptomatic or mildly pruritic).  The range of their clinical presentation is highlighted below:

  • Color:  light tan (
    image 1
    ) to black (
    image 2
    )

  • Size:  few millimeters to centimeters


  • Texture:  homogeneously greasy/velvety or hyperkeratotic/rough


  • Distribution:  typically trunk (
    image 3
    ), face, and extremities with sparing of the palms and soles


A red flag presentation is the explosive onset (<3-6 months) of numerous SKs (often in a Christmas tree pattern on the trunk), known as the Leser-Trélat sign (

image 4
).  This sign has been associated with internal malignancy (especially lung and gastrointestinal tumors) and warrants further investigation (eg, laboratory, endoscopic studies).  It is thought to occur in response to increased tumor production of cytokines or growth factors (eg, IGF-1, fibroblast growth factor).

Histology



Histological examination of SKs shows small cells resembling basal cells, with variable pigmentation, hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum), and keratin-containing cysts (

image 5
).

Diagnosis



In most cases, the diagnosis of SK is obvious based on clinical appearance; no further evaluation is needed and the patient can be reassured.  If further confirmation is desired, an examination with a dermatoscope may be performed, which would show whitish milia, irregular fissures and crypts, keratin plugs, and linear or fingerprint-like pigmentation.  When the diagnosis is unclear, especially when pigmented malignancies are considered (eg, melanoma), a skin biopsy should be performed for definitive diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of SKs consists of benign and malignant skin lesions that present with pigmented macules or papules.

  • Melanoma presents as an asymmetric, pigmented macule or papule with an irregular border and color variation (
    image 6
    ).  The lesion grows in size and changes appearance over time (eg, weeks to months).  In contrast, SKs are generally symmetric and homogenous in color with minimal change over time.  SKs are also hyperkeratotic (giving them a rough texture), a feature not present in melanoma.


  • Viral warts present as hyperpigmented or skin-colored cauliflower-like papules or plaques, affecting body areas typically spared by SKs (
    image 7
    ).  For example, condyloma acuminata (genital wart) affects the genitalia, perineum, or perianal skin; verruca vulgaris (common wart) mostly affects the fingers, palms, and soles.  Furthermore, thrombosed capillaries (not present in SK) are present in warts (
    image 8
    ).


  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) classically presents as a pearly papule or nodule with a rolled border (
    image 9
    ) and overlying telangiectasia, features not present in SK.  BCCs are typically skin-colored or pink but can also be pigmented (
    image 10
    ).  Unlike SKs, BCCs are not hyperkeratotic.


  • Common melanocytic nevi (moles) are caused by the benign proliferation of nevus cells, a type of melanocyte that forms clusters instead of single units evenly dispersed throughout the skin.  They first appear during childhood or adolescence, not during older adulthood as with SKs.  Presentation varies and ranges from brown macules (
    image 11
    ) to skin-colored papules (
    image 12
    ), depending on the location of nevus cell clusters (eg, epidermal/dermal junction, dermis).  Unlike SKs, moles are not hyperkeratotic.


  • Actinic keratosis is a precursor of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.  Despite the similarities in name, actinic keratosis is very different from SK.  It typically presents as a rough, scaly papule with an erythematous base in sun-exposed areas (
    image 13
    ).  When it is pigmented, it can resemble SK but typically lacks the "stuck-on" appearance of SKs.

Management



No therapy is required unless the lesions are causing discomfort (eg, catching on clothing, cosmetic concerns).  Treatment options include removal by snip/shave excision, cryotherapy  (eg, liquid nitrogen) (

image 14
), and electrodessication.

Prognosis



SKs are benign and do not progress to malignancy.  They may remain stable or grow slowly over time (eg, years).  Rarely, they may spontaneously resolve.

Summary



Seborrheic keratoses are classically brown hyperkeratotic papules or plaques with a warty, "stuck-on" appearance.  They generally develop in older patients (age >50) and most commonly affect the face, trunk, and extremities.  They are benign and are often asymptomatic.  Treatment (eg, shave excision, cryosurgery) is not necessary unless lesions become bothersome (eg, catching on clothing, cosmetically concerning).  When numerous seborrheic keratoses develop abruptly (Leser-Trélat sign), an evaluation for internal malignancies (eg, lung, gastrointestinal) should be considered.
